G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31, 31A, a.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, *Emily Johnson*, and respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification of the existing custody order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A, and 37, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the equitable powers of this Honorable Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, *Emily Johnson*, and respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification of the existing custody order pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A, and 37, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the equitable powers of this Honorable Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Bristol County Probate and Family Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6 and G.L. c. 208, § 28A, as both parties and the minor children reside within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Bristol County Probate and Family Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6 and G.L. c. 208, § 28A, as both parties and the minor children reside within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody or parenting order may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and that the proposed modification serves the **best interests of the children**.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting arrangements.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case does apply a best-interests-of-the-child analysis, but it does not say that the best-interests standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting arrangements. Rather, it applies the best-interests standard specifically to (1) the award of physical custody and (2) the removal of children from the Commonwealth, explaining how those best interests should be evaluated in that context. It does not purport to set a universal rule for all custody and parenting determinations, so citing it for that broad proposition overstates its holding.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child.” … “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting arrangements.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in deciding issues involving custody, the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the best interests and welfare of the children, and it applies that standard to both custody and visitation determinations. While the case does not catalogue every possible parenting arrangement, its reasoning makes clear that the best-interests standard governs determinations of custody and related parenting/visitation arrangements. Thus it supports the cited proposition in substance.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). Heard v. Heard, 323 Mass. 357, 375-377 (1948). Clifford v. Clifford, 354 Mass. 545, 548 (1968) ("sole question" is what is best for children’s welfare). … The "best interests" principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting arrangements.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses that custody decisions must consider the impact of domestic violence and repeatedly references the “best interests of the child,” but the key passages here are about requiring explicit findings on domestic violence, not about defining the governing standard for all custody and parenting determinations. The case assumes, rather than articulates, the best-interests standard and focuses its holding on how domestic violence must be factored into custody decisions, so it does not clearly stand as authority for the broad proposition that the best-interests standard governs all such determinations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. The Appeals Court gave great weight to this court’s Gender Bias Study ... that abuse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody.

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that significant **interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent** or failure to cooperate in joint decision-making may constitute a sufficient “material change.”
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about equitable credits against child support arrears and the statutory bar on retroactive modification; it does not discuss material change of circumstances for custody or joint legal custody. There is no analysis of interference with the child’s relationship with the other parent, nor of failure to cooperate in joint decision-making as grounds for modification. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about what constitutes a sufficient material change.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Consistent with the views of other jurisdictions, we conclude that a judge is not foreclosed by G. L. c. 119A, § 13(a), from determining whether ‘compelling circumstances of an equitable nature’ warrant the allowance of a credit for the payor’s fulfillment of his or her child support obligation ‘in a manner other than as directed by the original order’ but which nevertheless accomplishes the maintenance of the child as envisioned by the original order.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that significant **interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent** or failure to cooperate in joint decision-making may constitute a sufficient “material change.”
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion addresses removal standards and the best-interest analysis in a joint physical custody context, not modification based on ‘material change in circumstances.’ While it notes that relocation can impair a parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities and discusses interference with ‘frequent and continued contact,’ it does so via a quotation to the ALI Principles defining ‘substantial change in circumstances,’ not as a Massachusetts holding adopting that rule. The court does not state that interference with the other parent’s relationship or failure to cooperate in joint decision-making is, in Massachusetts law, a sufficient material change supporting modification; that proposition is beyond the scope of this decision.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]… (4)(c) If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility… the court should modify the plan… in accordance with the child’s best interests, taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.’”}

Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 240.raw_text: Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 240 (2008)
Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 240.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that significant **interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent** or failure to cooperate in joint decision-making may constitute a sufficient “material change.”
Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 240.case_name: Giuffrida v. High Country Investor, Inc.
Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 240.support_reasoning: The opinion in Pappas v. Pappas does not address child custody, parenting time, joint legal custody, or what constitutes a material change in circumstances for modification of a parenting plan. It concerns contractual rights to restaurant privileges, Chapter 93A business claims, defamation, and the anti-SLAPP statute. Because the decision never discusses interference with a child’s relationship with a parent or joint decision-making, it cannot be authority for that proposition.
Pappas v. Pappas, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 240.relevant_excerpt: The provided opinion text contains no discussion of child custody, visitation, parenting plans, joint legal custody, or material changes in circumstances related to parent–child relationships. It is focused entirely on contractual rights to dining and shopping privileges at a restaurant, business negotiations, Chapter 93A claims, defamation, and anti-SLAPP issues.

Miller v. Miller, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 989.raw_text: Miller v. Miller, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 989 (1986)
Miller v. Miller, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 989.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that significant **interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent** or failure to cooperate in joint decision-making may constitute a sufficient “material change.”
Miller v. Miller, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 989.case_name: Gendreau v. C. K. Smith & Co.
Miller v. Miller, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 989.support_reasoning: This opinion is not a family-law or custody case and does not mention children, parenting time, joint legal custody, or interference with a parent-child relationship. It deals exclusively with negligence and the proper measure of property-damage remedies arising from gasoline contamination. It therefore does not address, much less establish, any rule about interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent constituting a material change in circumstances.
Miller v. Miller, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 989.relevant_excerpt: On the defendants’ appeal there is no contention that there was insufficient evidence to permit a Superior Court jury to find the defendants negligent in connection with the contamination by gasoline of the properties and well water supplies of the plaintiffs. What is in dispute is the measure of damages applied by the judge on answers to special questions put to the jury, certain evidentiary rulings, and portions of the closing arguments of counsel for the plaintiffs.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court may further consider the **emotional well-being of the children** and patterns of **parental conduct that erode stability or trust** as bases for modification.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the statutory ‘best interests of the child’ standard and, in particular, on preserving stability and continuity of the child’s living arrangements under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). While it discusses stability and the importance of maintaining satisfactory existing placements, it does not frame its analysis in terms of emotional well-being or patterns of parental conduct that erode stability or trust, nor does it treat such factors as an explicit basis for modification. The case is about an initial custody determination (under § 10(a)), not modification, and does not clearly establish the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court may further consider the **emotional well-being of the children** and patterns of **parental conduct that erode stability or trust** as bases for modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly reiterates that the governing principle is the welfare and well-being of the child and requires consideration of all relevant factors and the relative advantages of the parental environments. However, it does not specifically discuss emotional well-being as a distinct factor, nor does it address parental conduct that erodes stability or trust as an articulated basis for modification. The case is more generally about applying the best-interests standard, not the more specific proposition stated.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child. … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment… and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

Helms v. Helms, 392 Mass. 660 (1984).proposition: The Court may further consider the **emotional well-being of the children** and patterns of **parental conduct that erode stability or trust** as bases for modification.
Helms v. Helms, 392 Mass. 660 (1984).case_name: Powers v. Freetown-Lakeville Regional School District Committee
Helms v. Helms, 392 Mass. 660 (1984).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether a school administrator’s transfer constituted a statutory ‘demotion’ under G.L. c. 71, § 42A and whether the school committee complied with that statute and the open meeting law. It does not involve child custody, family law, or any consideration of children’s emotional well‑being or parental conduct. The reasoning is confined to school employment and procedural protections, so it does not support the cited proposition about bases for modification in a child-related context.
Helms v. Helms, 392 Mass. 660 (1984).relevant_excerpt: The trial judge compared the differences between the high school and the middle school assistant principals’ responsibilities, taking into consideration eleven functions. He found that a transfer would change Powers’ duties. He observed that fellow professionals would perceive the transfer to be a demotion which would cloud Powers’ future employment prospects, notwithstanding satisfactory explanations for the move. The judge concluded that the transfer was a demotion. Further, he concluded that the protections of G. L. c. 71, § 42A, applied to Powers.
